results.headline: Finding Your Bliss? Losing Your Mind

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Meet Bill

results.summary_short: Male midlife crisis presents as pathological self-loathing in “Meet Bill,” an imperative to which the only sane response is: No thanks.

results.headline: From High School Student to Ruthless Madam

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Babysitters

results.summary_short: Until it crosses a shadowy line dividing serious comedy from distasteful exploitation, “The Babysitters” has the makings of an incisive satire of greed and lust in suburbia.

results.headline: A Cop in a Tailspin

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Vice

results.summary_short: “Vice,” a muddled, disposable crime thriller, has modest merits.

results.headline: Morning Hangover, Spouse and Jackpot

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of What Happens in Vegas

results.summary_short: “What Happens in Vegas,” one of those junky time-wasters that routinely pop up in movie theaters, won’t make you laugh much or at all.

results.headline: Gentlemen, Start Your Hot-Hued Engines

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Speed Racer

results.summary_short: “Speed Racer” sets out to honor and refresh a youthful enthusiasm from the past and winds up smothering the fun in self-conscious grandiosity.

results.headline: A Portrait of Perseverance

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Refusenik

results.summary_short: “Refusenik” falls short as entertainment because of the plodding, overly studious approach of the director, Laura Bialis.

results.headline: The Filling of an Empty Soul

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Memory Thief

results.summary_short: In “The Memory Thief,” a strange and melancholy journey to the heart of madness, a rootless young man finds meaning in the horrors of a stolen past.

results.headline: Caught Between Her Passion and Her Pension

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Previous Engagement

results.summary_short: More tired than the fantasy it promotes, “A Previous Engagement” aims at middle-aged women with the subtlety of a pitch for bladder-control medication.

results.headline: The Sights and Sounds of Oppression

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dilemma

results.summary_short: “Dilemma” is an earnest if schematic attempt to address conditions in Johannesburg under apartheid.

results.headline: The Killing of Innocents Faces a Dry-Eyed Dissection

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Battle for Haditha

results.summary_short: In “Battle for Haditha,” the British filmmaker Nick Broomfield revisits a wretched chapter of the war in Iraq.

results.headline: Struck by Love in a Moody Underworld

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of As Tears Go By

results.summary_short: “As Tears Go By,” Wong Kar-wai’s first feature film, heralds a new vision not yet in perfect focus.

results.headline: Dark Memories Abound

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fugitive Pieces

results.summary_short: For a tale spiked with so much torment, “Fugitive Pieces” feels remarkably soothing.

results.headline: Confronting the Perils of Puberty Squared

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of XXY

results.summary_short: The moody, surreal “XXY” explores the world of Alex, an intersex teenager navigating the treacherous emotional and hormonal rapids of uncertain gender.

results.headline: Lonely Boy’s ‘First Blood’ and First Pal

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Son of Rambow

results.summary_short: “Son of Rambow” is a likable, lightly sticky valentine to childhood, the 1980s and the dawning of movie love.

results.headline: Marilyn Monroe Returns Home to Her Husband, Charlie Chaplin

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mister Lonely

results.summary_short: “Mister Lonely” is enigmatic, its moods and meanings sometimes elusive, but nearly every frame is an image of arresting clarity and beauty.

results.headline: A Photographer of Pets and Perps

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Favor

results.summary_short: “The Favor,” a dreary, interminable drama written and directed by Eva Aridjis, is exactly one-third of a good movie.

results.headline: Diversity of Talent and Spirit
results.display_title: Hollywood Chinese: The Chinese in American Film

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hollywood Chinese: The Chinese in American Film

results.summary_short: A welcome entry in the constituency-cinema canon, “Hollywood Chinese” surveys a century’s worth of Chinese-American entertainers.

results.headline: Swinging Suburbia and the Sensual City

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Viva

results.summary_short: “Viva” is a startlingly pitch-perfect reproduction of the kind of gauzy sex movies from the 1960s and early 1970s that preceded the hard-core revolution.

results.headline: Heavy Suit, Light Touches

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Iron Man

results.summary_short: “Iron Man” is an unusually good superhero picture. Or at least — since it certainly has its problems — a superhero movie that’s good in unusual ways.

results.headline: My Best Friend’s Big Fat (Shouldn’t Happen) Scottish Wedding

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Made of Honor

results.summary_short: The romantic comedy “Made of Honor” adds tart satirical flavors to a cotton-candy formula without sabotaging the sugar rush.
